bestBHT.bht: After the Last Supper, Jesus and the disciples sung a hymn together before going out to the Mount of Olives. This act of singing the hymn served as a significant moment before Jesus would be betrayed by Judas. The purpose of mentioning this moment was to highlight how Jesus willingly arranged his time to meet Judas, who would soon betray him. This hymn sung by Jesus and the disciples was likely the Hallell, used during the Passover. It is worth noting that this event is not primarily focused on conveying Jesus' teachings.

Marvin Vincent: Sung an hymn. See on Matthew 26:30.
John Calvin: For, as we have elsewhere stated, their object was rather to embrace the history of our Lord’s actions than his doctrine.
They glance only at the fact, that he went out of his own accord where Judas was to come.
Their object is to inform us that he made such an arrangement of his time, as willingly to meet him who betrayed him.
Archibald T. Robertson: Sung a hymn (υμνησαντες). See Matthew 26:30 for discussion.
John Gill: And when they had sung an hymn,.... The Hallell, used at the passover..."
They went out into the Mount of Olives...
Judas now separated from them, and went to the chief priests to acquaint them how things were, where Jesus was going, and where they might apprehend him...

bhtAttempts.bht: After the Last Supper, Jesus and the disciples sung a hymn together before going out to the Mount of Olives. This act of singing the hymn served as a significant moment before Jesus would be betrayed by Judas. The purpose of mentioning this moment was to highlight how Jesus willingly arranged his time to meet Judas, who would soon betray him. This hymn sung by Jesus and the disciples was likely the Hallell, used during the Passover. It is worth noting that this event is not primarily focused on conveying Jesus' teachings, but rather to emphasize the sequence of events and actions leading up to his betrayal.

After the Last Supper, Jesus and the disciples sung a hymn together before going out to the Mount of Olives. This act of singing the hymn served as a significant moment before Jesus would be betrayed by Judas. The purpose of mentioning this moment was to highlight how Jesus willingly arranged his time to meet Judas, who would soon betray him. This hymn sung by Jesus and the disciples was likely the Hallell, used during the Passover. It is worth noting that this event is not primarily focused on conveying Jesus' teachings.

After the Last Supper, Jesus and the disciples sang a hymn together, most likely the Hallel, before proceeding to the Mount of Olives. This act of singing served as a significant moment as it emphasized Jesus' willingness to meet Judas, who would soon betray him. While the purpose of this event was more focused on the sequence of actions rather than Jesus' teachings, it highlights the deliberate arrangement of Jesus' time and his voluntary interaction with Judas.

After the Last Supper, Jesus and the disciples sang a hymn, likely the Hallell used at the Passover, before heading to the Mount of Olives. This hymn-singing moment serves as a significant event, highlighting Jesus' intentional arrangement of his time to willingly meet Judas, who would soon betray him. The emphasis lies not on Jesus' teachings but on the sequence of events leading up to his betrayal.

After the Last Supper, Jesus and the disciples sang a hymn together, possibly the Hallell used during the Passover. This hymn-singing moment holds importance in highlighting Jesus' intentional arrangement of his time to willingly meet Judas and face his upcoming betrayal. The focus of this event lies in the series of actions rather than conveying Jesus' teachings. The disciples going out to the Mount of Olives is mentioned, along with Judas separating from them to inform the chief priests of Jesus' whereabouts.
